title: 108_s1996
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Oglala Sioux Tribe Angostura Irrigation Project Modernization and Development Act". The Angostura Unit is part of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River basin program approved by Congress in 1944 to promote economic development, provide irrigation, and protect areas from floods. It includes irrigation of farm land in South Dakota and offers recreation and fishing opportunities. The Angostura Unit provides substantial recreation, fish and wildlife benefits. The Commissioner of Reclamation determined that irrigation at the unit yields $3,410,000 annually, while recreation at Angostura Reservoir brings in $7,100,000 annually. The unit impounds the Cheyenne River upstream of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, where there is a need for economic development due to high rates of unemployment and poverty. The Angostura Unit may have negative impacts on water quality and vegetation in the Cheyenne River on the Reservation. Modernizing irrigation facilities at the unit could enhance national economic development benefits and improve water efficiency and environmental restoration on the Reservation. Establishing a trust fund for the Oglala Sioux Tribe could generate economic development benefits comparable to those at the Angostura Unit. The Angostura Unit aims to provide resources for the restoration of the Cheyenne River corridor on the Reservation. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, definitions include terms like Angostura Unit, Fund, Pick-Sloan program, Plan, Reservation, and Secretary. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Tribe" specifically means the Oglala Sioux Tribe of South Dakota, and "Tribal Council" refers to the governing body of the Tribe. SEC. 101. Modernization and improvement of facilities at Angostura Unit as described in the Improved Efficiencies Alternative in the report. Cost to be nonreimbursable.

SEC. 102. Water saved through modernization to be delivered for fish and wildlife purposes and environmental restoration on Pine Ridge Indian Reservation.

SEC. 103. Authorization of appropriations. SEC. 103. Authorization of appropriations for section 101 is $4,660,000. The "Oglala Sioux Tribal Development Trust Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States with an initial deposit of $92,500,000 from the General Fund. The fund will also receive interest accrued on this amount from investments in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury invests a portion of the Fund not needed for current withdrawals in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Interest earned from these investments is deposited back into the Fund. Starting from the 11th fiscal year after enactment, interest will be withdrawn annually for the Tribe. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers interest earned on investments in the Fund to be used for payments to the Tribe as requested, without fiscal year limitation, after the Tribe adopts a plan. The Tribe must use payments for projects and programs outlined in the plan prepared within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Treasury Secretary cannot transfer or withdraw funds deposited, except as specified. The Tribal Council must make the plan available for review by Tribe members before finalizing it. The plan can be updated annually by the Tribal Council to reflect any changes. The Tribal Council must consult with the Secretary and the Secretary of Health and Human Services when preparing or updating the plan. The Tribe's activities under the plan will be audited annually as part of the single-agency audit required by the Office of Management and Budget circular A-133. The auditors conducting the audit will determine if funds were spent in accordance with the plan and include their findings in the audit report. The written findings will be included in the Tribal Council proceedings. The audit report is presented to the Tribal Council, prohibiting per capita payments to any member of the Tribe. SEC. 202. ELIGIBILITY OF TRIBE FOR CERTAIN PROGRAMS AND SERVICES. No payment to the Tribe under this title shall affect services or programs the Tribe is entitled to as a federally recognized Indian tribe or its members are entitled to as individuals. SEC. 203. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for administrative expenses of the Fund are authorized to be appropriated. SEC. 204. WATER RIGHTS. SEC. 204. WATER RIGHTS. This section clarifies that the Act does not affect the water rights of the Tribe based on various legal grounds and does not impact existing water rights held by any person or entity. The Act was passed by the Senate on November 19, 2004.
